content.body: Hixie: IE9 shows the h264 video for all mime types

hey MikeSmith
hey, it's nimbupani
annevk5: has anyone bothered to ask the biggest question of websockets: do we actually need protocol extensions?
like, I mean, what percentage of users / developers are actually going to use them?
yes, that point has been raised on a number of occasions on the hybi list
by maciej, ian, adam, and others
right, just thought I'd check
because really, I think we're going a little bit over the top with it all.
it's meant to be a simple transport method.
not the one-and-only ring-to-rule-them-all transport method.
like, sending a DVD over websockets, you probably should be doing that. Just use file transfers using http, that's already existent.
s/you probably should be doing/you probably shouldn't be doing
one-and-only-ring-to-rule-them-all transport method - nice
I'm sure you can easily imagine that you're preaching to the choir here. :)
good point.
I should get a few of the guys I know at Yahoo! to weigh in on it.
because I know some of the things they are planning to do / try with websockets are quite what it was necessarily designed for.
you going to the crockford tech talk at yahoo! on the 27th?
sadly not.
Yeah - I am looking forward to it
talking about node
(well, not that I've been invited to have a plane fair paid :P)
wait. 27th august?
heh
yep
next week

micheil: Have you seen http://www.glazman.org/weblog/newarchive/2003_01_05_glazblogarc.html#s87008479 for relevant background information?
micheil: http://ln.hixie.ch/?start=1041735552&count=1

Philip`, jgraham: do you think it'd be allowed to be mandated that for each protocol extension that a person / group wishes to have, that they show code for the implementation and provide documentation as to how it follows the original intent and goals of the websocket protocol?
like, not just psuedo code, but actual code showing how much complexity it would add to the parsing of the packets, etc.
Has anyone agreed to follow the original intent and goals, or even agreed on what the intent and goals are?

I always thought that they were to create a simple bi-directional communication channel for which browsers could communicate with servers and servers could communicate with browsers in an asynchronous way.
micheil: What do you mean "protocol extension"?
as in, anything added to the framing, handshaking or otherwise that isn't absolutely necessary for the communication of plain data
for instance, you message format, as simple as it may seem could be as simple as:
[frame-type][frame-length][frame-data]
frame-type being something like the flags currently defined
Right, I think it is reasonable to ask people to show the code for cases where they want complexity. And people have been doing that
frame-length being the 7bits or what ever we're currently at
jgraham: so far I haven't seen much code
I've seen outlines of the packet format, but no implementations of it
(I'm not too sure I'm even reading the outlines of the packet format correctly)
bbl.
micheil: There was one recent message with code
and someone pointed out that it assumed a particularly simple case
so there is evidence that code focuses the discussion somewhat
http://twitter.com/kangax/status/21506116839 hmm
I guess they are not doing that in quirks mode...

tidy

if I do -p1, I will just get +++ anolislib/processes/terms.py Fri Aug 20 00:00:23 2010
right?
Yes (I think)

o.O

has been pretty much asexual for the majority of this year

Will the real gsnedders please stand up?
I've been aromatic for the majority of this summer
too frigging hot
*aromantic
No, I did spell it correctly.
anyway, I have an actual questio about the new web standard, and specifically the relation between hN and sections
Damnit, confusing me!
yeah, you spelled it correctly 8-D
hmm, I should probably get the outliner back up
(outliner?)
http://gsnedders.html5.org/outliner/
Oh, it's working again
That makes it simpler
so, the question is the following: h1, h2, ... h6 represent headings of (implied) sections, with the relative rank being useful to determine whether a new section starts or just a subsection starts
is that correct so far?
If you use them that way, yes.  The other acceptable thing is to just use <h1> for everything.
with hn, n is meaningless within section
outwith of section, n is used to determine whether a new section or subsection starts
that's exactly what I wanted to get to. so if I do my sectioning explicitly for each heading, it doesn't really matter what section level I use, right?
right.
now, if I was using CSS for styling, one of the advantages of using different hN is that styling would be automatic, more or less
MikeSmith, isn't it at http://www.w3.org/Bugs/
annevk5: yeah
just typoed it
anyway, I think it's back up now
if I only use h1 and do the sectioning manually, I have to do something to say "style this way every h1 that happens under exactly N sections"
I think the mysql server was stopped and restarted
(more or less)
vals_: yeah
that's going to be a little painful 8-P
That's part of why :any() is proposed.
yes, :any() would help a lot, and not just in this case
hey guys
is there an easy way to reconnect a websocket when it's closed?
I'm guessing I have to manually implement that in my app...
gsnedders: aroudn?
*around
gsnedders: I've found you a FF bug that Opera handles as it should (IMO at least :))
Philip`: btw, hg diff seems to have neither a -p nor -d option
so its name is not wholly accurate
MikeSmith: They're optons on patch
maybe it should be call hg deficient-diff
diff doesn't have those options either
or maybe hg not-quite-as-deficient-as-the-diff-in-svn-diff
(at least not any with those effects)
scrolls back to read what Philip` said
ah
MikeSmith: patch.
i wonder how all these formal objections will be handled
hai hai hai
gsnedders, Philip` - I was just testing you guys
so, congrats in passing the test
Hixie: http://www.w3.org/html/wg/wiki/FormalObjection
i mean whether tim is going to do anything with them
is away:
(cos there's a number of things i don't particularly like the decisions of, and if tim is going to actually revert any of the decisions, it seems like it'd be worth giving it a shot)
Hixie: yeah, I imagine that same thought is crossing a few other people's minds
It seems like overruling a WG decision would piss off a load of people, probably more so than the people already pissed off enough to be raising it
So, uh, I'd doubt it.
Which is why, of course, most FOs just get stamped with a "Thanks for raising, move along now.", as far as I know.
TabAtkins: indeed

well i've only been on one transition call, which had an FO discussed, and while I don't think Tim had any idea what the objection was about, I will give him ample credit for apparently giving it quite a fair hearing
(to be fair it was an XBL2 issue so it's not clear anyone actually understood the issue)
So no, Hixie, I don't expect anything to happen with the FOs, and I don't think it would be useful to raise any yourself, unless the WG does something *really* stupid.
TabAtkins: I don't recommend acting on the assumption that nothing with happen with the formal objections
and for any given decision the WG had made, I reckon I can find someone who thinks it is really stupid

Oh, MikeSmith, while you're here: Who do I talk to to see if there's anything weird going on with w3's mailing systems that would cause someone to get spammed with over a thousand copies of one of my emails to the CSSWG over the past 2 months?
TabAtkins: I recommend going on #sysreq on irc.w3.org
and getting attention of the systems team
and trying to get a response in real time
kk
if the person who received the messages can forward them, with the headers
that would of course be a huge help
sigh -- http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10202
I should have advocated more strongly for a codecs attribute of some sorts
any type of media type parsing that involves parameters always gets ugly
annevk5: Does 12 opcodes seem like enough?
It feels like you could quite quickly be adding opcodes that mean "there are more opcodes"
Also, I am increasingly worried about the complete message length stuff. There are lots of SHOULDs and MAYs floating around which I expect to cause interoperability problems
I expect some servers will break with fragmented messages unless clients fragment from the start (e.g. simple servers that only deal with text)
not sure
i suspect you want something for video
maybe json
can't really think of much else
of course, famous last words and all :)
hmmm
y'know, a copy/paste API would be great
spec it

yeah, ::marker might solve that at some point
http://pastebin.com/tJMFxt2t
llrcombs, not a spec :)
content should be a list
so like a copybuffer?
jgraham, so I expect clients to not use fragments
so that you can have a history
jgraham, but the magical intermediaries might fragment
jgraham, but since the magical intermediaries are written much later
like with Jumpcut?
jgraham, deploying them might be impossible if servers do not play ball

+ I expect

"Going forward, I hope that the recommendations made after deliberation by the HTML A11y TF are taken more seriously by the wider group and not unilaterally dismissed."
I can't see any way to read that other than "We should make the final decision on anything accessibility-related, not you."
IIRC N-1 TF recommendations have gone over quite well in the wider WG
clearly #whatwg should send a similar e-mail :-P
Yeah, I was thinking of responding.
I probably shouldn't.

Stuff like: "The HTML5 A11y TF made the recommendation after much discussion and debate, onlist, off-list and via F2F.  We are very aware of the pros and cons of @longdesc but decided that its retention was currently the best option."
You could replace "HTML5 A11y TF" with "WHATWG", and "retention" by "removal".
But it's not worth getting into an argument over.  Won't accomplish anything.
i strongly recommend letting them make fools of themselves and not doing the same for yourself
I'm still waiting to see how the appeals turn out.
TabAtkins: do you know who is responsible for the video codec selection part of chrome?
e.g. what decides to use WebM vs Ogg vs H.264?
roc: ping
hixie: Scherkus, I'm told.
any idea if he's on #chromium?
scherkus: ah, he is
er
Ah, good.  I wasn't about to go searching down that list of /who.
i just typed "sch<tab>" :-)
but i wasn't expecting him to use his name :-)
That's only useful about 50% of the time...
hi
Hixie: you got roc back now too
woohoo, roc's here too!
roc: trying to work out what to do with <video> and content-type sniffing
Party!
Or maybe sleep
goes with that
roc: looks like we have five browsers and more or less five different implementations
roc: what's your position on this topic?
roc: http://hixie.ch/tests/adhoc/html/video/001.html and http://hixie.ch/tests/adhoc/html/video/NOTES may be of interest
personally I get the feeling we've raced halfway down to the bottom of the slippery slope of the poisoned well
and much as I hate to do it, we're likely to have to sniff, at least for <video> loads
and there's a pretty strong argument that if you sniff for <video> loads, you should sniff the same for browsing context loads
would you want to not even sniff for streams with missing content-types?
otherwise stuff like a "View Video" context menu item breaks oddly
I think sniffing for streams with no content-type is fine no matter what
*however* I think the other video guys in the office are more keen to hold the non-sniffing line than I am
what's the benefit of not sniffing when there is a type, given that these types are basically unambiguously sniffable? or are they not?
but they're not here right now
here's one

Hixie: I don't know. It's possible that in some containers you have to read a lot of data to figure out what codecs are present, where that information can be given in the MIME type. Our experts in that area are in the process of joining us...
oh you'd want to respect the codecs="" parameter even when it's wrong?
or do you just mean to throw out the content early?
the latter
Hixie: I assume if we were to sniff, we'd still not even try to load resources whose <source type> is something we cannot render?
i assume so
there wouldn't be any point in the type="" attribute otherwise
right
haven't tested that though
but that seems like a case that's much more unambiguously useful to honour
right now firefox seems to look at the mime type to pick the codec, and refuses to render mislabelled content, but i haven't tested the codecs="" parameter
s/codec/wrapper/
yeah, we try not to be first in the race to the bottom :)
(whatever you call the code that does that)
but we don't want to be last either :-)
hah

Hixie: with Matroska (and WebM, since the WebM spec doesn't exclude this "feature"), you may have to read an arbitrary amount of ASCII at the start of the file before you can identify it as a valid Matroska file (see the first paragraph of http://matroska.org/technical/specs/notes.html)
we should be honoring the codecs parameter correctly, we have code (and tests!) for that
but I'm going to propose that the WebM spec is changed to exclude that feature
roc: so if you supported codecs A and B, and a file used A but was labelled video/somethingsupported;codecs=B, you would not play it?
kinetik: wow, that's lame
kinetik: please indeed have them fix that!
Hixie: that is correct, that's what we do
or is it? hmm
thinks
no I guess it's not
i guess you don't support enough codecs to actually test that
or do you do the webm codec in ogg?
i guess that'd be one way to test it?
if the container type is mislabelled, we will reject even if both the label and the resource are something we support
yes
that i have indeed found
but we don't check that the codecs we got in the resource are the ones advertised
that would be pretty easy for us to do if we wanted to
doesn't seem like either of these checks are especially useful to the author or user
but they would definitely (if implemented everywhere) lead to mare accurately labeled content
the brutal truth is that almost all the time, if it's done consistently and can be done unambiguously in a predictable way, sniffing is the most useful for authors and users
i don't know that that's particularly brutal :-)
it feels brutal to me :-)
the consistency is the hard part
yeah, those are big "ifs"

Hixie: there's a small ease-of-implementation benefit for us the way we do things; we can set up the decoder based on the container label early in the load process, instead of having to buffer data, sniff it, construct the decoder, and feed the data back into it
but clearly that benefit is low priority
that's the container decoder right?
yeah

the chrome guy was telling me that one of his requirements is that the decoding happens out-of-process, and so he wants to just hand the bytes straight to that other process, and for some reason for them it's easier to just have that work without knowing the type
the container formats contain authoritative metadata telling you what the codecs are
we don't have to sniff again
though he said he could add (what he called "artificial") checks for the type
thankfully
if we could limit how much you have to buffer, would that help?
or is buffering any of the payload vs the headers a problem?
